text:
Hi I'm James Riley, and I'm an assistant
professor of business administration
in the Organizational Behavior Unit here— [laughter]
Hi, I'm James

Riley, uh, assistant—[laughter]
Now it all comes apart.

Hi, I'm James Riley,
assistant professor of business
administration [laughter].

Hi, I'm James Riley, assistant
professor of business administration

in the Organizational Behavior
Unit at Harvard Business School.
I study culturally embedded markets, in
particular, the contemporary art market.

And my interests grew
from when I was a child

growing up in Los Angeles
during the eighties and nineties.

When I found graffiti art as a
creative outlet and an expressive escape.

But as a child when my parents
would take me to the museums,

I noticed that I never saw
any of the art that I was making

or was being made around
me inside of these museums.
But fast forward

to today
and some of the most highly sought after

and highly valued
artists are in fact, graffiti artists.

And so it made me wonder,
how does something go from being value
less to valuable and even priceless?

So what really gets me
excited about the future of this research

is the advancement
in platform technologies and design

that enable the artists
to not only create value
through their art, but also to capture it.

I brought this coffee mug
because it reminds me of where I got

started in my academic journey
and how far I've come.
And it helps keep me grounded, centered,
and grateful
for where I'm at today.
